text: The Masters is a snooker tournament. It has been held every year since 1975. It is the second-oldest professional snooker tournament after the World Championship. With the UK Championship and the World Championship, it is part of the Triple Crown (snooker). Although not a ranking event, it is regarded as one of the biggest events on the World Snooker Tour.Turner, Chris. * == Winners == Year Winner Runner-up Final score Season Venue 1975 9–8 1974/75 West Centre Hotel, London 1976 7–3 1975/76 New London Theatre, London 1977 7–6 1976/77 1978 7–5 1977/78 1979 8–4 1978/79 Wembley Conference Centre, London 1980 9–5 1979/80 1981 9–6 1980/81 1982 9–5 1981/82 1983 9–7 1982/83 1984 9–5 1983/84 1985 9–6 1984/85 1986 9–5 1985/86 1987 9–8 1986/87 1988 9–0 1987/88 1989 9–6 1988/89 1990 9–4 1989/90 1991 9–8 1990/91 1992 9–4 1991/92 1993 9–5 1992/93 1994 9–8 1993/94 1995 9–3 1994/95 1996 10–5 1995/96 1997 10–8 1996/97 1998 10–9 1997/98 1999 10–8 1998/99 2000 10–8 1999/00 2001 10–9 2000/01 2002 10–9 2001/02 2003 10–4 2002/03 2004 10–9 2003/04 2005 10–3 2004/05 2006 10–9 2005/06 2007 10–3 2006/07 Wembley Arena, London 2008 10–3 2007/08 2009 10–8 2008/09 2010 10–9 2009/10 2011 10–4 2010/11 2012 10–6 2011/12 Alexandra Palace, London 2013 10–6 2012/13 2014 10–4 2013/14 2015 10–2 2014/15 2016 10–1 2015/16 2017 10–7 2016/17 2018 10–7 2017/18 2019 10–4 2018/19 2020 10–8 2019/20 2021 10–8 2020/21 Marshall Arena, Milton Keynes 2022 10–4 2021/22 Alexandra Palace, London 2023 10–8 2022/23 2024 10–7 2023/24 ==Finalists== Name Nationality Winner Finals 8 6 14 6 3 9 3 2 5 3 1 4 3 0 3 3 0 3 2 3 5 2 3 5 2 2 4 2 2 4 2 0 2 1 3 4 1 3 4 1 1 2 1 1 2 1 1 2 1 1 2 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 0 3 3 0 2 2 0 2 2 0 2 2 0 2 2 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 0 1 1 * Active players are shown in bold == References == Category:Snooker tournaments
